div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

REMARKS.

The general weather conditions took place yesterday. The sun was obscured by clouds and there was comparetively little sunshine. This morning opens bright and cheerful,with a light S.E. breeze and a falling barometer. A slight change in the weather conditions may be expected during the day.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY. THE FRONTIER QUESTION.
div.p: Sir Edward Grey, Seoretary of State lor foreign Affairs, replying in tbo Housee of Com- nion to a question but by Sir Wilfred Iawsoi to the subject of the difficulties now existing botween the Khédivial Govornment and the Sublime Porte on the subjeot of the Sinaitio frontier, stated that no ultimatum had been sent by the British Government to Turkey. It was obvious that the action of the. Ottoman troops was an aggression and that the Egyptian Administration cannot allow it to continuo. The matter was, however, now the sobjeot of negotiations.
Constantinople. March 27.
The Ministers are deliberating regarding the Akaba question. ( Reuter)

Up to the time of going to press no news had boon received in Cairo from Constantinople as to the answer of the Tarkiah Ministers to the demand of the Egyptian and British Governments, In well-informed oirolea It is believed that Tebah and Qabah will be evacuated by the Tarkish troops and that the dispute will be satisfactorily settled. At the same time, it would, in onr opinion, be onwise to oonnt upon an immediate answer on the part of the Porte, and we should reoommend our readers not to regard Tarkish i fficial procrastination as a sign of any hostile p nrpose on the part of the Ottoman Government.

div.head: ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
div.p: Thanks to the good offices at the American Government the outlook at Algeciras is good, for owing to the intloenoe of the United States the Conference's deliberations have reached the last stages.

div.head: AMERICAN MINES.
div.p: The "Times" correspondent at New York itatee that the joint conferenoe between the bitominoas miners and the mine owners hse failed. The miner's convention meeting is to be held todsy. It is expected that a strike will be then deolered. The sitnation in regard to the anthracite outlook is equally gloomy. A strikeof the entire mining industry is probable.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe, via Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 4.45 p.m. to day.

div.head: Mena House Hotel.
div.p: This hotel has been purchased by the Nun govich Hotels Company and not, as has been stated in some local newspapers, by Nungovich Bayin his personal capacity.

div.head: Union Artistique Française
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the above society will be held on Thursday next at 9 p.m., when the new rules formed by the committee will be submitted for approval.

div.head: The Fean of the Prophet.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive granted an audience yesterday at Abdeen Palace to Bbeikh Tewfik El Bakii, head "of the religions Bheikbs, who requested his Highness to permit the Monied of the Prophet to be held as usual. His Highness gave permission for the Monied to be opened and promised to attend the ceremony.

div.head: E T. C.
div.p: Mr. J. H. Davey, who telieved Mr. Giles and has been in charge of the Alexandria station of the Eastern Telegraph Ccmpany for the last tour months, has.been transferred to Malta. Mr. Giles retorns to Alexandria in a month or so. Meanwhile Mr. J. H. Mm. Gavin is acting as superintendent.

div.head: Le Bottin.
div.p: Mr. A. Burke-Honau, Inspector General for abroad for the great. French directory known as ' Didot Bottin," and member of the Colonial Press Syndicate, has arrived at Alexandria in connection with the annual revision of this great work. The new edition at the "Bottin,'' so far as Egypt is concerned, is very up-to-date and the oontente are quite abreast of the great commercial and financial develop ment of the country. Mr. George A. Adib, the well-known commission agent, ie the representative for Alexandria.

div.head: ROAYAL VISIT TO CAIRO.
div.p: PROGRAMME OF STAY.
Tho following is the programme of the visit to Cairo by tho Prinnce and Princcss of Wales :
WEDNESDAY, 28th.

H.M.S. Renown arrives at Burs dating tho afternoon, and will be met by Mr, M. de C. Findlay, Councillor of Embassy, and Lowa J. N. Watson Pacha, A D.C. to H. H. tho Khedlive, Ibrahim Halim Pacha, Goverirrof Buex, and Kalmakam Bchaloh Iley, Commandant Bun Canal Police.
THURSDAY, 29th.

A special train will leave Buos Suez Station at 10.30 a m, conveying all survents and baggage that oan bo sent on in advance — arraugmuunts will lie made for Incheon for the servants en route—and the train is duo to arrive at 3.30p.m.„ at Cairo Station, where vans will bo in readiness to convey the luggage to Abdeen Palaco.

Their Royal Highness and snita will disembark from H, M. B. Renown without any ceremonial, in plain clothes, about 12.0 noon and proceed tip Cairo by tho royal special train duo to leave Bust Docks station at 12.30 p m. Lunch will he sorved in tho train at 1 p.m. and tea before arrival at Cairo. As regards lunoh T. R, H.'s and, if thoy désire, four others will lunch in tho dining compartmont of saloon No. 1178, the remainder of tho suite will lucnh In the 2nd dining room at the dining car, and tht servants will havo their lunch iu the same car as soon as the suite has finished.
Accommodation for T.R.H. to change will lie provided in saloon No. 1170, and similarly for the suite In saloon No. 1171.

The royal train will only atop at Banha and Zagatig for any langth of time. The other stops are Fayed, Nefiche, and Tal el Kebir, but those are optional and for watring purposes only, and Cairo will bo roftohnd at 5.20 p m. On arrival at the station T.R.H. will be met by :
H.H. The Khedive
H.H. Prince Mohammed Ali Pacha.

Ferik Ahmed Seki Pacha, Grand Master of Ceremonies ; Ferik Youssof Zia Paoha, Chief A.D.C. to H.H. the Khedive; Lowa Hussein Mobarrem Paoha, 1st A.D.C. to H.H. the Khedive ; the Ministers, the Etrl of Cromer, the Advisers, the Under Secretaries of State, the Governor of Cairo, Mr. A. D. Alban, British Consol ; Lews Ellis Mansfield Pacha, Commandant Cairo City Police ; Brig.-General Bollock and commanding officers and heads of departments of the Army of Occopation ;
Ferik Sir Reginald Wingate Pacha, Sirdar, and commanding officers and heads of departments of the. Egyptian Army ; civilians in plain clothes ; officers in full-dress uniform.
Guards of honour will be famished by tho 1st Battalion, under Major C. L. E. Rubert- son Eustace ; and the 3rd Battalion E.A., posted ontside the railway station.
The route to Abdeen Palace will be lined by troops of the Army of Occupation and the Egyptian Army. The Procession of the railway station will be formed as follows:
DETACHMENT MOUNTED POLICE.
1 Sergeant 2 men H.H. Body Guard
1 Officer 30 men ,, ,,

Second Carriage (State Lardau, 4 horses).
H.R.H. the Prinooss of Wales H.H. Prince Moh. Ali Pacha

Sergeant 2 rnen

The Countess of Crouler

A guard of 100 men of H.H.'s Body Gaard and H.H's. Infantry hind will, to posted at Abdeen Palace, where T.R.H. will be met by De Martino Pacha, Direotor General of Daira Khassa ; Fabrioins Pache, Architect of Khédivial Palaces.
In the evening private dinner at Abdeen Palace.
Friday 30th.

T.B.H. will leave Abdeen Palace at 11.40 a.m. and drive opt to Afibassieh where H.R.H. will inspect the 1st Battalion K.R.R.C. on the ground between the British barraoks and officers quartors at 12.15 p.m.

T.R.H. will subsequently lunoh with Lt. Col. Markham and the officers of the mess. Drive baok afterwards, arriving Atdeen Palace about 3 p.m. Leave Abdeen again about 4 p.m. and drive, to Kasrel Çfil Barracks,' where, R.H. will present the 2nd Royal Ianiskilling Posihers with colours.
Subsequently T.R.H. will have tha with Lt. Col. Cox and the officers at the mess, returning afterwards to Abdeen Palace, where T.R.H. Will drive.
Saturday 31st.
Morning left vacant -for visiting places local interest.
Lunch at Abdeen.

At 3.30 p.m. the Prinoqas of Walos, accompanied by tho Countoas ol Cromer, will drive from Abdeen to Pont Litnoun Station and proceed at 3.45 by special train to Koubbeh Palace to visit H.H. the Khedivah, returning by carriage to Abbassieh (about 4.45 p.m.) to view the Egyptian Army Military Tonrnamont, which will bo held on the Observatory parade ground, where Her Royal Highness will meet H.R.H tho Prince of Wales, who will have proceeded there direct from Abdoon Palace by carraige.

H H. the Khedive will be present at the Military Tournament, arriving thorn from Knubboh shortly before H.R.H. the Prince ot Wales. Subsequently T.R.H. will drivo bank to Abdoon Palaoe, 'where H.H. the Khedive will bold an offioial dinner party at 8 p.m.
Sunday April 1st

T.R.H. will attend Divine Servioe at All Saints' Cburoh at 10.30 a.m., alter which thoy will return to Abdoon Palaoe, leaving shortly before 10'clock to lunoh with Brigadier General Bullock. Leave thereat 8.85 p m., drivo to tho landing stage bohind the British Agonoy, ombark on H.H's lannoh Ness in el Nil, proceed to north lido of Embaboh railway bridge, where thoy will ombark on H.H's. yacht Said Rabbani fur the Barrage, which will be reached about 4 p.m. Visit the Barrage, and gardens, returning too Cairo by stoamor at about 8.45 p.m H.H. the Khedive will accompany T.R.H. on the visit to the Barrage.
Private dinner at Abdoon.
Monday 2nd.

T.R.H. will leava Abdeen Palaoo at 8.25 a.m. for Cairo station, leaving tbero at 8.40 a m. by special train due a( Bedraohein at 9.10 a in. Proeeed to Sakkara, arriving there about 11 a.m. Visit the Serapoum and Temple, lunch at Mariette's House. Loavo Sakkara about 3 p.m. Embark on board H.H.'a yacht Tenet el Bahrein and loavo Bodraohein 4.30 p.m., returning to Cairoa bout 6 p.m. Tea on route.
Private dinner at Abdeen.
Tuesday 3rd.
Morning left vacant.
T.R H. will leave Abdeen Palace about 3.30 p m. and drive to the race course to attend the Bedouin raoes, returning afterwards to Abdeen Palace.
T.R.H. will leave Abdeen Palace at 7.50 p.m. to attend a dinner party at the British Agency followed by a reception.
Wednesday 4th.
Morning left vacant.
T R H. will leave Abdeen Palace about 4 p.m and motor ont to Mena, where they will have tea at 6, subsequently dining in the Government Honse at the foot of'the Pyramids.
Thursday 5th.

T.R H. will leave Cairo for Port Said. The procession and general arrangements for their departure will be similar to those of their arrival, except that the British gnard of honour will be formed by this 2nd Battalion Royal Ianiskilling Fusiliers, under Major C.A. Wilding. T.R H. will leave Abdeen Palace at 11.25 a.m. and the special train will depart at 11.45 a.m. Lunch will be served in the train at 1 p.m.
Arrive Port Said at 4.15 p.m , when T.R H. and suite will reembark on board H.M.S. Renown.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: The Egyptian Estates have sold to the Building Lands Company a parcel of land, 10,500 square pics in ares, situated in front of the College of the Jesuits at Alexandria. The price paid for this land was L E. 36,000.

The Committee of the London Stook Exchange has fixed April 6th as a sperial settling day in Egyptian Estates, Ltd.—£150,000 5 per cent. debentures of £100 each, Nos. 1 to 1.500, and has ordered this security to be quoted in the official list.
A London correspondent writes :

There has been no particular feature this week beyond the scarcity of shares of the Egyptian Estates. There are evidently buyers on this side, but from all appearances most of the shares have been taken by yonrside, where the bayers evidently know when they bave a good thing on. It looke as though those here who would like to become interested will not be content to sit down owing to this scarcity of shares, and will ultimately try to obtain some of those in yonr country, and this should still farther harden prices, as I cannot think the astute Egyptian will part with his, without seeing a good margin of profit on the transaction.

div.head: MENA HOUSE GYMKHANA.
div.p: We are asked to remind car readers that a gymkhana will take plaoe at Mena House Hotel on Friday, the 30th inst., at 3 p.m. The Egyptian Army. Cavalry Band will play during the afternoon and tea will be served on the gronnds in the large tent free of charge.

There will be four donkey and four horse races. The ladies Nomination Race, on hourses, where competitors have to ride in costume, should prove a special attraction. It is stated in the programme that competitors have tea provide their owe costumes, but the management have wisely arranged have some costumes on the ground,which can be obtained tree of charge.
There are no flat races, except one for ladies, distance two furlongs., This alteration in the programme has been made to keep professionals out, and give the gymkhana the charaoter it should have.

div.head: EGYPT AND AMERICA.
div.p: THE WADI RAYAN.
DIPLOMATIC NEGOTIATIONS.

The C. W. Hon. lddiugs, American Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General at Cairo, has forwarded to Washington a despatoh from Boutros Paoha Ghali, on behalf of the Ministry for Foreign Affairs, to the effect that the application of the Washington Government in rogard to the claims of Mr. Cope Whitehonso was made in due form. Mr. Iddinga has receivod further instruotions by cable from Washington to forward to the Department of State complete copies of the papors relative to the case.
The following is the official statement of the claims of Mr. Cope Whitehouse as contained in Senate document No. 104 :

It appears from the papers transmitted to the Committee on Foreign Relations, and published in this doonmerit, that Cope Whitehouse, an Amerioan citizen, discovered certain depressions in thp Egyptian Desert lying to tho sonth of the Fayomn in the spring of 1882. The map published by the Government of the United States, in 1882, shows no trace of any snob depressions ; and in a communication from Lord Cromer to the Marquis of Salisbury, it is conceded that if was the work of Mr. Cope Whitehouse in the following terms :
"There has been every disposition to examine Mr. Cope Whitehouse's projeot in a fair and friendly spirit, and to allow him full proffit for the important discovery which he has unquestionably made.
"I now proceed to explain to your Lordship how tho matter stands at present :

"Mr. Whitehonse's scholastic researches led him to believe that a depression existed to the sonth Fayoum. Levels were taken and it was found that this depression actually did exist. There is good hope that it may be utilised to the benefit of /Egypt. 8bonld this hope be realised, Mr. Cope Whitehonse will have a fair olaim to a reward proportionate to the benefits, which, after fall examination, it is found will accrue to the government and population of Egypt from his disoovery ''
Cope Whitehouse's 'claims are:
First. That he entered the Wadi Raiyan nnder the land laws of Egypt and has a right to a patent for an area of abont 250 square miles, on payment to the Egyptian Government of ten cents per acre.
Second. That under the statute laws of Egypt he is entitled to pot this depression in commnnioation with the Nile.

Third. That the project itself tor the utilization of this depression, as a flood excape and atonge reservoir, is wholly his work and that it is not open to the Egyptian Government to make any of these plans withont compensation to him, and that this projoct was in a complete and perfeot state more than seven years ago.

Fourth. That he is entitled to the depression known as the Wadi Mcellah ; and, on the 17th of March, 1887, made application in due form for a concession thereof, and that the Council of Ministers at its meeting on the 16th day of Hay, 1888, deoided to adjourn the consideration of the matter ontil the question of the Raiyan projeot should bave been settled. That this question of the otilization of the contignons depression was sohmittei to a technical commission of engineers in 1894, and that it was then decided that it would not be expedient for the Egyptian Government to adopt it. That noder these cironmstanoes, be is now, and ever since has been, entitled to receive a "hodja" for the Wadi Muellah.
Fifth. That the statement made on page 91, that the Foreign Minister of Enypt, says "Whitehouse has no possible claim to 'hodja' and that dossier mentioned does not exist," is clearly incorrect.
Sixth. That, on January 06, 1905, Hon.

J.W. Riddle, Diplomatic Agent and Consol General of the United States, informed the Hon.Francis B. Loomis, Assistant Seoretary of State,that Lord Cromer, the Diplomatic Agent and Consul General of his Majesty's Government and Sir William Garstin, Adviser of the Ministry of Poblio Woiks, stated that ; "If Mr. Whitehouse attempted to start a company, (in the United States), and begin operations on his own account be would he prevented by the anthorities." The reason alleged was that "the won of irrigation and tbo distribution of water is one which will always be direotly nnder the control of the Government, and private enterprises will not be permitted." But the work of storing water in the Wadi Raiyan has nothing whatsoever to do with the subsequent use of that water, and aorording to Mr. Cope Whitehouse, the Egyptian Government has do right whatsoever to prevent his acquiring his title deed on payment of ten oents an acre, so soon as the amqrant of land for: which pay or interfere with his making such use of his vacant and unoccupied land as he may think proper.

He refers, to the common law of Islam, the Capitulations, and the statutory law if Egypt a sample to second his protection, provided the Government of the United States will undertake to see that they are enforced in his behalf.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COMPANY LAW.
div.p: The Rights of Shareholders.
A NICE LEGAL POINT.

A very interesting legal and financial question has been raised by the recent judgment of the Cairo Mixed Court in the case brought by M. Boutigny against the Nungovich Hotels Company, and against Nungovioh Bey personally, with a view to obtaining the annulment of the decision of the general meeting of the Company of May 18th, 1905, anthorising Nungovich Bey to take an interest in other companies. The Court non-suited M. Bontigny, not on the facts added baton ths ground of inadmissibility. The point raised is of great interest especiàlly in Egypt. To intervene at the general 'peetings of meat companies, the shareholders are obliged to deposit their shares at the establishments notified in the notice advertising the meeting. These banking houses with the exception of the Credit Lyonnais do not pat on the "bordereau" the numbers of the shared deposited. Therefore when the shares are handed back there is a chance that the depcs itors do not receive baok the identical shares which they handed in. It appears to be a legal quibble of the subtlest order as , the following "attendus" show .
Attendu que les 'défendeurs exoipent de recevabilité pour défont de qualité de la part do demandent.
Attendu que Boutigny agit en sa qualité d'actionnaire lésé par la délibération do 18 mai dernier.
Attendu que poor avoir cette qualité, il doit posséder aujourd'hui les mêmes actions qn'il possédait k oette date.

Attendu qu'il verse an dossier un procès- verbal de l'assemblée dn 18 mai, d'où il résulte qu'il était alors propriétaire de 25 aotions et an oertifioat délivré le 17 février 1906 par The Anglo-Bgyptian Bank, et ainsi oonçn : "M. Henry Bontign..,. titres existant sons votre dossier ohez nous oe jour : Actions 25 Geo Nungovioh Hotels."
Attendu que ni l'un ni l'autre dooument ne prouve les numéros des aotions qu'il mentionne ni nie donne anonn antre moyen de les identifier.

Attendu que ces documents prouvent qn'è denx d.tes séparées par nn intervalle de 9 mois le demandeur possédait 25 aotions, mais raé, et que dans tous les oas il n'est pas pins difficile pour Ini de prouver un fait conoernant ses propres biens, que pour les défendeurs de pronver le oontraire demandent fait appel aa fait que le 18 çnai 1905 le bureau n'a pas exigé la
ne pronve pas que les 96 dn 18 mai 1905 Ismailia villa. This evening they dine with sont les mêmes que les 95 do 17 février 1906. the Austrian Consul at Cairo nod then prooeed.
Attendu en l'espèce, qo'ils ne donoeot même to a soirée, followed by a danoe, given by M. pas lien k une présomption d'identité, vn le Moise Cattani.

laps de temps, le caraotère de oes actions et la I Tomorrow, 150 of the sailors of the squadron profession da demandeor, courtier en valears are going up to Cairo to moke on exoursion de son état to the Pyramids and see the sights.
Qu'en effet le borean n'avait qa'k s'assurer qne les actionnaires admis k l'assemblée avaient le nombre d'aotions exigé.
Attendu qu'il résulte que l'actdon est irrecevable.
Attendu que l'action oontre Nungovich l'est également
Par ces motifs, déboute.

div.head: THE PREMIER'S BANQUET.
div.p: The annual official dinner of H.B. Mustapha Pacha Febmy took place at the Savoy Hotel on Monday evening, 72 guests sat down at the beaatifully deoorated table. H.E. the Prime Minister had on h's right Maie de Villebois and on his left Mrs. Iddings. Opposite the Pijme Minister sat H E. Qhezi Mukbtar Paoha, having on his right Mme Maskens and on his left Countess de Wedel. The other guests included : Fakhry Pacha, Sir Reginald and Lady Wingate, Mazlonm' Paoba, Gen. and Mrs. Bollock, Mr. and Mrs. von Mohl, Abani Paoba, Baron and Baroness de Tranttsnberg,Come Thaddé, Bolesta Kodzlebrodzki, Sir Vuoent Corbett, Sir William E. Garstin, Sir Malcolm and Lady McUlwraith, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. M. de C. Findlay, Mr. Iddings, Comte Wedel, Major and Mrs. Johnstone, Mirza Ali Asghar Khan, Mr. and Lady Valda Machell, Crookhank Paoha and Mas. Crookshank, Mr. Alexis Smirno, Contosse de la Sala, Mr. and Mrs. Perry, Mlles de Villebois, Sir Horace and Lady Pinching, Mr. Rioakis, Mme Mueller, Comte de Vanvineux, De Martino Pacha and M ne De Martino, Miss Mohl, Imail Sarhaok Paoha, Adly Paola Yeghen Chewki Pacha, Lewis Mansfield Pacha, Mr. Bernard, Mr Carter Wilson, Lord Bdward Yousef Zia Paoha, Mr. B. Mueller, Abdel Halim Paoha Assem, Fatby Bey,Neghih, Mr. Booiteau Bey, Mr Douglas Dunlop, Mr. Webb, Souder Pacha Frhmy, Brmoli Bey.
The large salle des fêtes is well as the hall had been beautifully decorated with plants, and the whole of the arrangements were perfect and greatly appreciated.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d'Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 P.M
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Count Kodzibrodaki, accompanied by Rear Admiral von Jedina called on Lord Cromer this morning at the British Agency.
M. Maximoff, Russian left for Asia Minor.
Mr. Lamploagh, who is leaving for England on the 31st inst., will hold a second exhibition of bis pictures for two days only, on the 28th and 29th inst.

The Rev. Thos. J. Finney, who has been spending the post winter on the American Mission Dahabieb, the Ibis., visiting the villages in Upper Egypt, returned yesterday to Alexandria, where he will again take up his duties in conneotion with the work of the Mission in this district.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: The creditors meeting for the appointment of two co-syndics has been postponed till tomorrow (Thursday). Me. Carton de Wiart, on behalf of the creditors, has demanded the appointment of a committee of surveillance composed of three members.

The Sucreries have proposed Harari Pacha and Meesrs. Hume, MacLanghlin, Harchitz, and Nans. Me. Padoa Bey suggested the appointment of a French candidate at the last meeting, and the names of MM. Goussard and Sontsr have been suggested by Me. St. Plancet.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive gave andience yesterday to the Ministers, to Ali Pacha Hilmy, and to Mr. Donglas Dunlap, and at 10.30 a.m. received Rear-Admiral Jedina and bis staff.

div.head: AUSTRO-HUNGARIAN SQUADRON.
div.p: A gala dinner was given at Abdeen at 7.30 p.m. yesterday in hononr of the officers of the Austrian squadron now at Cairo. Admiral von Jedina and his staff lunched with the Austrian Diplomatic Agent yesterday and are invited to lunch to-day at Maitre Fotica's Ismailia villa. This evening they dine with the Austrian Consul at Cairo and then proceed to a soiree followed by a dance, given by M. Moise Cattaui.

To-morrow, 150 of the sailors of the squadron are going up to Cairo to make an excursion to the Pyramids and see the sights, while the Austro-Hungarian colony will give a Venetian fete at Shepheard's Hotel on the same evening to the officers of the fleet.
Our Austrian guests are obviously deter mined to make the most of their stay at Cairo.

div.head: H.E. THE GOVENOR.
div.p: H.E. the Governor, owing to orders received from the Ministry at the Interior, had to leave for Cairo yesterday evening after having attended the banquet given him by the members of the Municipal Commission at the Khédivial Hotel.

After the arrival of the Prince and Princess of Wales at Cairo, his Excellency will return here to take definite leave of his friends and be present at the banquet to be given in his honour at the Mohamed Aly Club by the Conaolar Corps, which has had to be postponed.

The acting Governor this morning handed the patents and decorations of the Medjidieh Order (3rd class) to Baron Alfred de Menasce and Soliman Bey Abani, and of the 4th class Osmanieh to Ahmed Bey Ayoub.

div.head: EGYPT'S GREAT PROBLEM.
div.p: The most pressing problem at the present moment in Egypt is the question of salaries, and every day a new category of people demand an increase in their stipends. Yesterday we announced that the employee in the Minieh Moudirieh had petitioned the Finance Ministry to have pity on them and increase their salaries in view of the constant rire in prices. Today the Ulema of Alexandria are agitating for higher pay. They claim that they only receive L.E. 5 a month, while their confrères, who corns to Alexandria from Al Azh receive L.E. 8 per month. They have accordingly petitioned the Khedive and the Chancellor of Al Azbar University to enquire into their grievances, and to bring pressnre to bear on their president, Sheikh Mohamed Shaker, to raise their salaries.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Rameees sailed from Liverpool yesterday afternoon and is due here about the 10th proxo., with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The S.Y. Argonaut will leave Alexandria for Naples and Marseilles on April 2. Full particulars msy be obtained ot Messrs. John Ross & Co.
As we go to presn we learn that her arrival has been signalled.

div.head: Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
div.p: River Transport of Goods Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.
Agents at Alexandria:
Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld

Several articles of the police projeot have been adopted. A settlement is believed to be probable oa the lines ol a France-Spanish police force controlled by the diplomatic body at Tangier, though an inspector will be appointed by a nentral power. (neuter)
The possibility of Connt von Bulow's resignation continnes to be disonssed and the hereditary brines of Hohenlohe Lengerburg is even mentioned as a successor. (Reuter)

div.head:
RESERVE FORCE BILL
MR. HALDANE'S MEASURE

div.p: Mr. Haldane introduced a Reserve Forces Bill, which, it is understood, provides machinery for enforcing liability of seivice in the else of reservists residing abroad, and also authorises enlistment for the Army Reserve of residents in India and the Colonies as a special provision of local defence. ( Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIAN NATIONAL ASSEMBLY.
FINANCE MINISTER'S PROPOSALS.

div.p: The Minister of Finance is reporting to his colleagnes the financial measures which may be submitted to the National Assembly. He refers to the difficult financial and economic position reaniting from the war and famine. He proposes, besides an inoome tax, indirect taxes inolnding an increase of doty on tobacco; taxes on electric power, lighting by gas and oandles, and a duty on paper. He is opposed to an increase of the tax on sugar. (Reuter)
A great agitation is taking plaoe here and in Moscow in favonr of a railway and factory strike when the Douma meets. ( Havas)

Students made a riotous demonstration against a production at the National Theatre of a play in French. The cavalry charged the rioters. 250 persons, inclnding women and children and 150 police and soldiers, were injured. Two of the latter have since died.
(Reuter)
The bituminons coalminers in America have presented an ultimatnm to their employers demanding 5 % increase of wages. A strike is considered inevitable. (Reuter)
A number of French miners are resuming work pending the referendum regarding the advisability of going on strike. (Reuter)
The Italian Government yesterday acquired the sonthern railways, thus completing their nationalization. (Renter)
King Edward will lengthen his stay here till April 2. (Havas)
The Govoner, Mr. Curry, has reached the camp.
Lincolnshire Handicap. 1. Ob; 2 Dean Swift; & Roseate Dawn.
24 fan. 20 to 1 against Ob ; 9 to 2 Dean Swift ; 11 to 2 Roseate Dawn. Won by a head. One length between 2nd and 3rd.(Reuter)

div.head: CHURCH SERVICES.
div.p: Mansourah.
April 1.—5th Sun. in Lent. Evensong 6.30.

div.head: KHARTOUM 50 YEARS AGO.
div.p: In Sir Harry Johnstone's ' new work on the Nile Quest there is an interesting passage on the pleasant lifs at Khartonum fifty years ago. We make the following extracts as they will compaie with the reminiscenoes evoked by Abbate Pacha _in his able discourse before the Khédivial Geographical Sooiety on Saturday last :—

Life in Khartonm between 1850 and 1860 was by no means devoid of attractions. Several of the Europeans who made it their head quarters brought ont their wives with them. Others were married to handsome Abyssioian women. The booses of Egyptian style were comfortable and cool. The place swarmed with strange new beasts and birds ; indeed, nearly every bonse inolnded a monagerie in one of its sards. A great slave market brought before the eyes of astonished and interested Europeans nearly all the Negro types from as far west as Wadai and Darfonr, from the confines of Abyssinia on the east, from the lands of the naked Nile Negroes on the south ; stalwart, lighter-coloured, bearded Nyam-Nyam cannibals from the south-west, coal black madi here and there an Akka pigmy, thin-shanked Dinka and Shrink, sturdy. Bungo, and handsome Gala. "There ain't no Ten Commandments" might with some justice have been said of Society at Khartonm. At any rate it was much untrammelled as regards the more wear some convention of civilised life. Nobody inquired if M. Dubois was legally married to Mme Dubois, and perhaps the treatment of the doubtful Mme. Dabois as a respectable married woman by blue-eyed strait-souled Mrs. Jones ended by Mme. Dubois becoming legally united to ber spouse later on at Cairo, and finishing the rest of her life as a happy and perfectly respectable person. The air was full of wonderment. Improvements made year by year in fire-arms resulted in marvellous big game shooting. Through there weri bad fevers to be got iu the Bahr-et Ghazal, the climate of Khartonm itself was not neoessarily unhealthy. The post seems to have arrived across the desert on camels at least once a month. The tyranny, sooial and administrative, of the British military officer and his dame was not to come for many years ; the "smart" hotel was absent provisions were good, plentiful and cheap. Those are times that the African explorer of to-day looks haok upon with something like a sigh.

div.head: EGYPTIAN'S ESCAPADES.
div.p: WHOLESALE SUBURBAN BURGLARIES

The fact that an Egyptian should become, an expert London burglar shows that the race has capabilities not yet realised, as the following extract frond the police reports in she latest London new papers to hand will show :
An Egyptian subject, giving the name of William Tobin, ms charged, at ths South- Western Court, with committing a number of burglaries in ths neighbourhood of Wands worth-common and Balham.

Prisoner, a well dressed man, is said to have carried on a systematic course of thrift, but has hitherto evaded arrest, bis respectable appearance having thrown aside suspicion. In the early morning of the 2nd it be was seen to emerge from the side door of 5 Mayford road, Balham, the residence of Mrs. White, a widow lady. A constable, noticing the man looking about, asked him his business. Prisoner, making no response, dealt a blow at the officer, and immediately retreated into the house, closing the door in the constable's face. The officer rang up the inmates, and found that the man had esoaped, the place being left in confusion, and money stolon froms one of the rooms. He was not seen again until a week ago, although in the interval many other robberies were oommitted in ths neighborhood. Police-constable Crowhnrat stopped him as he left 10, Ravenslea-road, the residence of Mr. Richard Parry, a surveyor. Tobin indignantly resented the constable's interference, and said he was going to town on business. The officer unbuttoned the man's overcoat' and discovered a large quantity of valuable propoity, including silver plate and jewellery, concealed in his numerous pockets. Ho was removed to the polioe station, and the property thlis discovered was claimed subsequently by Mr. Parry, whose house was entered during ths night by one of the back windows, and by Mr. Joseph Law, corn miller, 21, Mayford-road, he, too, being visited by thieves under similar ciroumstances.
It was mentioned that accused came out of prison in January last, after undergoing a sentence for theft.
Mr. De Grey committed him for trial.

div.head: TO AVOID QUARANTINE.
div.p: A WONDERFUL GAS
MORE EXPERIMENTS AT ALEXANDRIA.

As we announced in onr last issne, some most important siperiments were made yesterday on the Khédivial Company's S.S. Prince Abbas for ihe purpose of demonstrating how easy it is by means of a new process to free a ship of all microbes and vermin. This afternoon a farther experiment is to be made in Alexandria Harbour on the S.S. Assouan, and we have no doubt will meet with equal success.

Ion the case of the Prince Abbas, a representative of the "Egyptian Gazette" was present at the famigation, and he was astonished to see the masses of cockaroatches found dead in the foreoastle. A quantity of rats also were discovered in No. 1 hold and- these likewise proved nnable to withstand the penetrating fumes of what is now known all the world over as 1 Clayton Gas. As this invention has, we hope, come to Bgypt to stay, it will not, be out of plaoe to set before onr readers the method employed in generating this wonderful chemical prodaot.
The Clayton Gas.

The Clayton gas is produced by burning at a high temperature ordinary rolled sulphur. The apparatus itself oons sts of a generator, in which the sulphur is bnrnt, an engine and blower, and a cooler. At the commencement of the operation the discharge-pipe is led to the bottom of the hold or enoloaed space. Another pipe, which is railed the "retain," is led to the generator. When the maobine is started the air for generating the gas is taken from the return, formed into gas in the generator, and delivered into the bottom of the hold or other enolosed space by the discharge, thus ensuring a thorough diffusion of the gas. What Clayton gas is has not yet been definitely defined, but its extraordinarily fnherent diffusive properties have been demonstrated times without number. Dr. Calmette, the oelebrated chemist and bacteriologist of the Pasteur Institute at Lille, found that this gas contained S.O. 2 ; S.O. 3 ; and S.O. 7. But he was of opinion that it probab'y contained some of the higher combinations of oxygen and sulphur difficult to determine. Professor Simpson, the expert on plague and typhoid fever, who rarried out many experiments with the gas, was of the same opinion. It was for this reason that in his able treatise on plague he railed it a polyoxide
Faots and Possibilities.

It is needless here to go into the enormous potentialities of this wonderful invention. Bnt the following extraots from the official reports of the various sanitary authorities sprak for themselves. Dr. Tamayo, in his report to the Peruvian Government on the best means of combating plague, says (page 47) : "In conclusion for the maritime prophylaxy of plague, the measure to be ohosen is the employment of Clayton gas, which unites all the advantages of the ordinary sn'phurons aoid and of cir- bonio aoid gas without their inoonvenience. It is more active than these gases, perfeotly barm less to merchandise, possesses a notable power of penetration, offers not the slightest danger of fire, and guards against aooidenta by asphyxiation. The Cayton apparatus effects the sulphuration in a comparatively short time and thanks to the system of aspiration and fotoed delivery, produced a homogeneous gaseous mixture in all the atmosphere of the enolostd spaces." Then again, Erneat Hill, M.R.C.S., L.R.C.P., D.P.H., Health .Offioer of the Colony of Natal, in his third annual report for the year 1904, says : Clayton's fumigating apparatus is highly spoken of and I consider that a vessel leading harbour that bears a certificate of having been fumigated by the Clayton process should be, and probably would be, relieved from quarantine restriction when entering other ports." From Copies of letters we have seen in the possession of the Clayton representative now at Alexandria and from captains of several vessels to their owners, Mr. Hill's declarations bave been entirely substantiated in praotice. Again, the Health Physician to the Board of Health of Guayaquil says: ––

"The laborious task of disinfecting all vessels arriving from.the South has been carried out with scrupulous rigour, and it is undoubtedly owing to the work performed by the station under my oharge that the port has been kept free of the terrible invasion which menaoed and still menaces us with the bonbunic plague. It is my duty to record that the efficiency of the Clayton apparatus is indisputable, since the practical work of the station leaves not the "lightest doubt as to the power of the gas employed to destroy all classes of germs and bacilli. The disinfection accomplished by the apparatns is, withont any doubt, the precar tionary efficacious means of preserving the port from the most remote peril of contagion.

From the foregoing statements our readeis will see that the efficiency of this system is acknowledged. In London the Metropolitan Asylums Board did not feel themselves justified in Belling the one-time smallpox hospital ships stationed at Gravesend until they had satisfied themselves that there would be no danger of infection after they let their hands. It was for this reason that they applied to the Clayton Company to fumigate them and, to prove that there would be no chanoe of contagion, they placed hundreds of tubes of microbes all over the vessels, which, after the fumigation, were found to be sterilised. That they were justified in this action is proved by the fact that although they were taken away and broken up immediately afterwards, not a single case of fever resulted.
Work to be done In Egypt.

It is obvious that such an apparatus is badly wanted in Egypt, and we are glad to hear, that a limited liability company is shortly to be started in this country for the purpose of installing the Clayton plant at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez. We are informed that these plants will beoapable of disinfecting the largest vessels entering these ports in from six to eight hours. Portable machines will be supplied for the disinfection if houses, hospitals etc., and for the "deratisation" of shoonahs. Nor is this all the scope of the gas. It will be equally efficient in extinguishing cotton fires in shoonahs, in destroying weevil, etc., in grain, in the famigation of sewers and cesspools, in short the Egypt for vermin-killing and sterilising in comparatively enclosed spaces is nearly illimitable. The invention is therefore bound to meet with univeral cceptance in Egypt, and from what we have seen ourselves we can foretell a most prosperous career for the new company, for its sphere of beneficient action in Egypt is very wide.

div.head: THE ABOU HAMED-KARIMA RAILWAY
div.p: Mr. John Ward, F.S.A., the well-known Egyptologist, author of "Our Sudan," has sent the following letter to the "Times" :—

Sir,—The brief notice in "The Times" of the 10th inst of the opening of the railway line from Abu Hamed to Karima will give great satisfaction to antiquaries, as well as its importance in opening the rich province of Dongola to connection with the markets of the East.
This railway was alluded to as being much required in Lord Cromer's report of 1904.

It has been made entirely with native labour in eight months, under the direction of Marauley Bey and his able assistant-director, Midwinter Bey. This for 138 miles of railway is almost a record, for the district is hilly and difficult for engineering. The terminal station, Karima, is not laid down on any published map, the course of railway is marked on the index map to my work on the Sudan. It almost reaches to Dongola, on the opposite side of the Nile, visiting Merowe by the way.

The interesting pyramid fields of Jebel Baikal (Napata), Kurru, Zama, Mayal Norri, Tangasai are all now rendered accessible to travellers. No doubt the Government will speedily, provide rest-houses at each group of pyramids in this anoient centre of Bgyptian civilisation. These regions have not been generally accessible to antiquaries since the days of Lepsius, with the exceptiod of the I several recent visits to Jebel Baikal by Dr.Bndge. The opening of the new railway will be bailed with delight by those interested in the 200 pyramids and other wonderful antiquities of the Sudan. Costly caravans, with camels, tents, and escorts have hitherto been the only way of reaching these regions, as the direct military railway to Khartoum necessarily avoids this historic but unknown oonntry, and by which not one anoient site oould hitherto be visited.
Belfast, March 13. John Ward

div.head: ALEXANDRIA TRAMWAY CO.
div.p: THE MOTOR BUS SCHEME.
To the Editor of me "Egyptian Gazette "

Sir - A few days ago you rectified the statement made by some local newspapers as to a definite decision having been arrived at by the board of the Alexandria Tramway Com pany on the subject of starting a motor-omnibus service by qualifying it as being merely a scheme under consideration. In to-day's issue of the "Gazette" I see that a new company has been started at Alexandria one of whose objects is motor bns traotion, and as a shareholder of the Tramway Company I should like to point ont the pressing necessity of not allowing any other oompany to forestall the Tramways in*'organising an efficient bus service, for the motor omnibns most neoessarily displace the tram. To support my contention I give the following extract from a London newspaper : —

"The motor-omnibus has sounded the knell of the tramway. Where there is a oonstant procession of suoh omnibuses it will be impossible for people to reach the tramways in the twiddle of the road without grave risk, while the tramlines cannot be brought dose to the kerb beoause of obstruction from vehicles standing and unloading by shops and warehouses.

"When fair allowance is made for the coat of depreciation, which is practically overlooked in the London County Council tramways and many municipal systems, the motor-omnibus is within fractional limits (l-20d.) as cheap as the tramway. The cost of operating a tramway is about one fifth of a penny per passenger per mile when the cars are running foil, and that of operating a motor-omnibus about one farthing.

"If allowance is made for the lessened difficulties to other traffic caused by the motor-omni bus, its increased flexibility, and the loss inflicted through the blocking of roods while the rails for tramways are being laid, the pecuniary advantaged probably on the side of the motor-vehicle. Moreover, the foot that the motor-omnibus is in its infancy, and that the dopreciation charge which is being made per mile is at present very heavy, as the result of the want of knowledge as to its behaviour, must be taken into account.

It is now little more than a year since the first really effective motor-omni buses were placed upon the London streets, and already the success of the new vehiole is beyond dispute. Before 1904 omnibuses of this type were hampered by ill considered legislation, else there is little doubt but that three or four years ago almost as good resolts might have been obtained p perhaps, indeed, one of the gravest problems of London transit might bave bren settled before ever the Traffic Commission held a single sitting. -

"It is estimated that while 350 motoiromni- buses are running, over a thousand are on order for work in London alone, but the diffiiulty for the makers is to execute the order, not to obtain them. An amazing revolution is thns in rapid process of accomplishment, and it has prcceeded with all the greater speed beransd the ioral bodies, which have now become a grave obstacle to progress, have not been able to hamper the development of electrical enterprises.

"The advent of the motor-omnibus, even in its present undeveloped condition, has seriously affeoted the fiuanoial prospects of tramway, and in future the competition of the motor will be even more formidable than it is to-day."

If an energetic motor-bus company appears on the scene here, it may very easily take the wind out of the sails ol the Alexandria Tramway Company. These extraots show it is being done in the case of the trams in London.

The great necessity is that each omnibus . should be fitted with decent first-class accommodation, so that the first class passengers by trams would travel by these motor-buses as well. The new single wagon trams of the Alexandria Tramway Company conveniently cater for both classes and the motor-omnibuses could do the same. Unless the Tramway Company take up the matter in earnest they will find themselves outstripped by other companies. It is to be hoped therefore that the Board of Directors will decide at once and take time by the forelook—I am, etc.,
An Alexandrian.
Alexandria March 27.

div.head: ABBASSIEH LAND.
div.p: Sir, —In yesterday's edition of the "Journal Officiel' (page 552 1 notice that the Government is offering for sale several plots of land at Abbasaieh, at from P.T. 35 to P.T. 60 per square metre. I should like to know the relative position of this land compared to the huge area conceded to M. Empain and Boghos Pacha Nobar at the rate at L.E. 1 per feddan. We were told reoentlythat the "obligation" to provide trams, electric light, and water threw a heavy burthen on the concessionaires and made the cost price of their land P.T. 85 per metre. It is a curious form of finance to debit such expenditure and to ignore the foot that these should prove highly remunerative works. —I am, etc.,
An Anxious Enquirer.
Cairo, March 28.

div.head: ENTOMOLOGICAL EXCHANGE.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Dear Sir,—Is it possible that you would be kind enough to publish the following in your paper. I am a oollector of butterflies and moths (not a dealer) and would like ods or two'of your readers who collect, to exchange a few butterflies and moths caught in yonr district, for some that I have raught or bred here. The inseots to be enolraed in triangular papers.
Hoping you will oblige by publishing this.— I am, yonrs sincerely,
H. Wilkinson.

div.p: Of the United States Treasury Recommends Pe-ru-na.

DR. LLEWELLYN JORDAN, Modical Examiner of the U. S. Treasury Department, graduate of Columbia College, and who served three years at West Point, has the following to say of Peruna:

Allow me to express my gratitude to you tor the benefit derived from your wonderful remedy. One short month has brought forth a vast change and I now consider myself a well man after months of suffering.
Fellow sufferers, Peruna will cure you. —Llewellyn Jordan.
Doctors have been loathe to oudorse a catarrh remedy because catarrh and catarrhal diseases have puzzled the medical fraternity for many decades.
The popular endorsements that Poruna lias received at the hands of the people have induced a great many doctors to try the remedy.
More prominent physicians use and endorse Peruna each year.
Dr. A. Morgan, 214 Cater street, Indianapolis, Ind., writes :

"Regular physicians do not, as a rule endorse patent medicines. I have, however, found In my practice that Peruna la a notable exception and not at all like any other medicine generally sold as patent medicine. '
"In examining it I find that ii is a scientifically prepared medicine, composed of herbal remodies ot high medicinal value.
"It Is a specific for catarrh of the head, lungs or stomach, a fine remedy for female troubles, and invaluable to mothers and children.
"After fevers or other protracted illness, it is one of tho best tonics I know of to rostore the systom to normal condition and I recommend lt to convalescents.
"It is a high class family remedy, good for young and old."—A. Morgan.
Peruna occupies a unique position in medical science. It is the only internal systemic catarrh remedy known to the modical profession to-day.
Robert R. Roberts, M. D., Washington, D.C., writes:

"Through my own experience as well as that of many of my friends and acquaintances who have been cured or relieved of catarrh by the use of Hartman's Peruna, cap confidently recommend it to those suffering from such disorders, and have no hesitation in prescribing it to my patients."-Robert R. Roberts.
Catarrh is a systemic diseaso curable only by systemic treatment. A remedy that cures catarrh must aim directly at the depressed nerve centers. This is what Peruna does.
Poruna immediately invigorates the nerve centors which give vitality to the mucous membranes. Then catarrh disappears. Then ratarah la permanently cured.
Pe-ru-na Contains No Narcotics.

One reason why Peruna has found permanent uao in so many homes is that it contains no narcotic of any kind. Poruna is perfectly harmless, lt can be used any length of time without acquiring a drug habit. Peruna does not produce temporary results. It is permanent In its effect.

It has no bad effect upon the system, and gradually eliminates catarrh by re-moving the cause of catarrh. There are a multitude of homes where Peruna has been used off and on for twenty years. Such a fating could not be possible if Périma contained any drugs of a narcotis nature.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, 27 Mare.

A Londres, le Consolidé anglais a réactionné hier de 1/8 h 90 3/8. L'U.aifiés a, par oontre, gagné 1/8 à 106 1/8. La National Banket l'Agrioole sont restées :nvariées à 28 et 10. La Daira est renseignée en reprise de 1/8 à 18 1/2.
A Paria, l'aotion Crédit Fonder Egyptien a perdu 2 franos à 796.

Notre marché des valeurs a montré, ce matin enoore, très peu d'animation. Les cours de la plopart des valeurs sont restés, h peu de choie près, oe qu'iU étaient hier et les jours précédents ; les petites variations qui se sont produites sur quelques titres n'offrent qu'on médioore intérêt. Cette inaotivité doit être, assurément, attribuée h la liquidation de fin de mois, qui parait devoir être laborieuse.

La National Bank, délaissée, a fléchi h 27 7/8 —16/16 l'aotion ancienne, et 27 1/16 la nouvelle. L'Agricole s'est traitée aux abords de 10 pour o'Oturer h 9 7/8—15/16. Le Crédit Foncier est revenu h 797. La Daïra a faibli è 18 1/4—5/16. L'action Land Allotment a baissé à 3 7/8.

L'action Immobilière est remontée h 390 et la part de fondateur a fléchi è 630. L'aotion Enterprise and Development est revenue il 12 ; la part de fondateur a avancé à 17 8/4. L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux est restée h 4 1/4 ; la part de fondateur a été cotée L.E. 15.

La Brasserie des Pyramides a gagné 2 franos à 145. Les Ciments ont fléohi à 82 et la part de fondateur à 20. La part de fondateur Menzaleh est retombée à 120. Les Omnibus du Caire se sont inscrits h 34 1/2-35.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, lesNungovich ont avancé à 17 7/16 et les Baehler à 6.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estâtes se sont échangés 5 2 1/16; la part de fondateur à 13 5/8. Les New Egyptian ont olôtnré à 35sh. 6 ; les Sait and Soda h 23 sh. ; les Walker and Meimaraohi a 7/8 et les Egyptian Constructions a 1 9/16.
On rapporte que la Compagnie Agricole du Nil seiînt 4 la veille de oonvoquer- ses actionnaires.on assemblée extraordinaire pour délibérer stpr une proposition d'augmentation du capital social.
Ce capital, qui est de Frs. 3,000,000, divisé en 12,000 aotions de Fra. 250 ohaoune, serait porté au double par l'émission de 12,000 actions nouvelles.

Les résultats de l'exercie qui doit se olô turer fin courant ont été tellement encourageante que la Sooiété aurait déoidê d'augmenter ses ressources afin d'étendre son champ d'action et donner plus de développement a ses affaires.
Ilserait même question d'une émission d'obligations Ique l'on demanderait a l'assemblée d'âutorirer aussitôt après l'augmentation do capital.
Le Conseil d'administration de la Société Egyptienne de la Daïra Sanieh a approuvé aujourd'hui le rapport qui sera présenté 4 l'assemblée générale du 30 courant.

Contrairement aux rumeurs mises en cirou lation, nous croyons savoir que la nouvelle suivant laquelle l'assemblée aurait 4 statuer sur nne deuxième répartition de £ 10 par action n'est pas tondée. L'assemblée se prononoera simplement sur la fixation du dividende statutaire.
On assure que l'émission de la Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Co. aura lien très probablement vers le 15 avril prochain.
Il serait offert 4 la souscription pnbliqne 10,000 aotions, qui seraient émises a L.E. 10.
An sujet de la Compagnie Immobilière d'Egypte, nous lisons dans le "Moniteur des Intérêts matériels" de Bruxelles du 18 mars.

Le dividende de 18 a 20 fr. dont noos avons parlé pour l'aotion de capital mettrait la rémunération de la part de fondateur entye 12 et 20 fr. Depuis l'augmentation du capital, le dividende de la part de fondateur vaut, en effet, d'après la formule de répartition statutaire, quatre fois le superdividende de l'action de premier rapg. Les distributions correspondantes de l'année dernière ont été de 17 et des fr; les 12,000 aotions nouvelles ne concouraient pas 4- oette époque, aveo les 12,000 actions primitives, au partage des bénéfioes. Si dans l'avenir' l'aotion de oapitaj arrivait, par exemple, 4 toucher 25 fr., et en supposant que le capital reste ce qu'il est, il reviendrait 40 fr. a chaoune des 6,000 parts de fondateur. "
Il est rappelé aux actionnaires de la Sooiété d'Entreprises Immobilières et de Travaux que le deuxième versement de L.E. 1 par action doit être effeotué, au plus tard, le 2 avril proohain.
Aux termes de l'art. 7 des Statuts, toute somme non payée passé ce délai porte de plein droit intérêt au taux de 9 % l'an en faveur de la Société.
Les cours du coton sont en petite réaction on Amérique. Hier, le disponible et le Mai ont perdu 5 points respectivement, et l'Ootobre 8.
Lee arrivages ont été de 15,000 balles oontre 24,000.
Le marohé de Liverpool est plus on moins stationnaire.
loi, le Mai, qui a fini lourdement hier soir 4 20 9/32, a ouvert ce matin 4.20 6/32 pour olêtorer a 20 8/16.

MM. H. De Vries et Boutigny, agents de obange, se chargent de l'exécution de tous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Brnxelles, Auvers, Liverpool et New-York.
La Cironlaire quotidienne de la maison est envoyée sur demande.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourdhui a midi et demie)
Le marché a débuté très faible mais ihs'est peu à pen' raffermi sur les va'ours solides : a National, l'Agrioole et la Delta Light.
La National olôtnre 5 27 7/8 l'anoienne, h 26 15/16 la nouvelle, l'Agrioole à 9 15/16 et la Delta Light a 12 1/4 acheteurs, soit une hausse respective de l/l G environ.
Eu reprise également la'New Egyptian a 36, la Daïra 4 18 5/16, la Brasserie des Pyramides a 144, la Crown Brewery a 232, et les Tiamways d'Alexandrie a 177.
La Land Allotment reste a l'action et a 170 la part de fondateur.
L'Oasis (Corporation of Western Egypt) cote 1 7/16 tandis qu' a Londres il est ferme 4 1 7/8.
L'Investment est en bonne tendance a 11/32. .

L'Egyptian Estates Co.a vendu a la Building Lands Co. un lot de terrains de 10.500 pios carrés, pour la somme de 86.000 L.E. terrain, situé en faoe du Collège des Jésuites fait partie des propriétés achetées récemment par les Estâtes a M. Alderson.

div.head: SEMOULERIE PERFECTIONNEE
div.p: "LELYS"

J'ai l'honneur d'informer le public et plus spécialement ma respeotable olientèle que, tout en gardant mon moulin 4 farines de Tarsoos (Turquie d'Asie), fondé en 1890, je viens d'installer 4 Alexandrie une seraoulerie de tout dernier modèle fonctionnant d'après les systèmes perfectionnés les plus réoents de Franoe et de Suisse. Grèce à ma longue expérienoe dans ce genre d'industrie, ainsi qu'aux moyens exceptionnels dont je dispose pour m'approvisionner en blés de tout premier choix en Syrie, dans le Levant et en Russie, j'espère pouvoir donner pleine et entière satisfaction sous tous les rapports.
Dans l'espoir que vous voudrez bien me conserver votre pratique et faire l'essai du produit de ma nouvelle usine,
Agréez etc.
Gabriel Marino.
Mon bureau se trouve à côté de la Poste de Ras-el-Tin.—Téléphone N° 17-68—et la fabrique dans le même quartier, Rue Gouda.
P.S.— On peut se proourer dans le même établissement du son, des criblures et de la farine

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINES EXPLORATION.
div.p: " A GREAT AND RICH MINING AREA"

The fifth annual general meeting of the thareholdera of the Egyptian Mines Explora tion Company, Ltd., was held on Friday the 16th March at Winchester Honse, E.C., Mr. Tyndale White, Chairman of the company, presiding.
The Secretary (Mr. E. S. G. Malins) read the, notice convening the meeting and the report of the auditors.

The Chairman said,: Dealing with the balance-sheet, yon will observe that the isanod capital remains, as at the last balance-sheet. On the debtor'side there is nothing to which to draw yonr attention except the itrm of £1 66S 13s. 4d., calls not yot payable at that date. To tarn to the credit side, the cash in hand is £2.262 5s. 4d., to which we must add the amount receivable on shares snld, £1,078 Os. lid., pins the calls payable, £1,666 13s. 4d., totalling £5,007 Is. 7d. The expenditure on development work, with which 1 shall deal later on, is £16.450 18s. 5d. The next item on the oredit side to which I wish to call your attention is 124,999 £1 shares in the varions companies shown in the account. The Board has not seen its way: to place a valuation on this vastly important asset ; bat yen, gentlemen, who have read the report submitted and Mr. Alford's report, will folly appreciate its great potentialities. Before calling yonr attention to what this company has aceimplisbed, let me for a moment remind yon that we all went into this oompany as a pure speculation, knowing prrotioally nothing about the mineral resources of the large area placed in oar hands for development. We might not have fonnd anything at all. and none of' ns would bave had any oanse of complaint.
The Um Rus Mine,

But, gentlmen, we, the pioneer mines exploration company in Egypt, under the able advice of oar mining engireer, Mr. Alford, have steadily opened up what we believe to be a great and nob mining area ; more than this, we have exploited and proved our first mine, Um Has, and it has passed from the status of a "prospect" to that of a crashing mine. As you will see by our report, Um Rus has yielded in the last ten months of 1905 4,295 czs of bar gold, giving the average per ton of 17.24 dwts, with a sterling vaine of £14,721, and since the rnd cf the year 1,204 tons, yielding 833 ozs, valned at £2.849. Every new mine has its initial difficulties, which gladlly disappear ; bat. carefully and economically managed, Um Rus should be a valuable mine -not rich, like Atallah, or with big ore bodies like Semna, but a good, steady- going proposition, in which the shares should be a sound investment. In our report we have drawn your attention to three mines on onr large concession—the three areas we are at present closely engaged in developing. But it mast be borne in mind that these are only the forerunners of other which are on our concession. No doubt we have suffered, as all pioneers must so fiat, from the expenses incidental to the establishment When Mr. Alford made his first journey through our concession he was practically the first European who had ever visited this part, of the desert. Everything had to be carried on camel backk, wells have had to be sank, depots established, labour arranged for, and the innumerable little annoyances' all pioreers experience had to be overcome. All these troubles have meant expense. The time ban now come when we should approach the enterprise in a spirit, not of adventnrers seeking a shadowy fortune in an unknown desert, but, of buisness men who have pnt a certain amount of money into a business, and find it increasing so rapidly that they require farther capital, and have then to consider whether such capital could be proferably employed or not. We have to-day 1,500 shareholders in this company; we starrted with 50. We have spent in the five years we bave teen at work about £40,00, and our friends the subsaiary companies have spent some £47,000.
The Atallah.

Having sold our first mine, Um Rus, let me now draw yonr attention to the Atallah, Semna and Bridia mines, owned by the Central Egypt Exploration Company, Ltd., the Fatira (Egypt) Company, Ltd. ,and the Fatira (Egypt) Exploring Company, Ltd., in that order. These companies have actively work the mines, (luting the year under consideration, and I have no hesitation in saying that the results arrived at, as shown in Mr. Alford's reports, are highly satisfactory. In Atallah we have opened up a mine of exceptionally high vaines, showing an assay table of phenomenal values steadily maintained. Taking Mr. Alford's report, yon will see that at No. 1 shaft in the 170 ft level at 47 ft the vein ie 14 ins wide, and shows 11 dwts, going into schist, and for 30 ft there was 9 in of quarts, with a value of 2 on 7 dwte, and for the next 28 ft, with a width of 8 ins. its value was 7 on 16 dwts. Turning in the opposite direction, and driving through at 94 ft in the shaft to ancient workings (you will observe how deeply the aroirnta followed down the vein—a conformation or its richness), the vein struck here was 34 ins wide, with a vilue of 4 czs. The third vein was driven on and at 45 ft from the shaft, the vein being 7 ins wide, shewed a vaine cf 3 czr. The crosscut pot in to perfect the ventilation intersected the middle vein, and some 18 ft of driving on this showed the vein to be 4 ins wide, with a value of 10 czs of gold to the ton. This shaft was sunk to a depth of 225 ft, so you see we are getting well down on the veins. There a crosscut put in reeobed the vein below the fault mentioned above, and it was found that it had widened, to 18 ins ani its value was 4 ozs. It is very satisfactory to me to be able to announce that since the annual report wss posted to the. shareholders we have received advice from Mr Alford that the vain on the Atallah mine has been recovered below the last break in the footwall and the main win, and shows 24 ins wride, with 17 dwts of gold per ton. This is a most encouraging feature in the development of this promising mine. No. 2 shaft, which is on tin north eastern portion of this vein, shews that at the 195 ft level the is a very significant point—for a distance of 202 ft driven on the vein, with a width of 8 ins all over, the value average 1 oz 7 dwts. The incline shaft, No. 2, sunk to a depth of 220 ft. met at that depth the ancient workings, and a pillar left by the aniciepts showed the vain 6 ins wide, having a value of 7 ozs 16 dwts. I must leave to you the pleasure of studying the report of tbo superintending engineer on this rich mine.
The Semna and Eridia.

Rich as the Atallah mine is, we have in the Semna mine one of exceptional characteristics. It has been said that mines in Egypt do not disclose large bodies of one, and to these critics I command Mr. Alford's report on Semna. Here in No. 1 shaft at a depth of 75 ft the vein was 12 ins wide, a unvalued 2 ozs 5 dwts person, and at 65 ft from the shaft the vein was fonnd to be a body of quartz 15 ft thick, and at 70 ft the vein was 60 ins wide, with a vaine of 2 czs 18 dwts of gold. In No 2 shaft wo have driven 23 ft to a depth of 50 ft, following the vein which was 48 ins wide, with 5 dwts of gold. The level to the westward struck old workings at 23 ft from the shaft, and at this point the vein in 65 ins wide, assaying 18 dwts. Well may crar engineer say, "We have in this mine by fit the largest. mases of gold-bearing quartz we have met with in any of our mires "Lastly, gentlemen, we have to consider the Eridia mice, where steady, hard mining work has been continnonsly carried on in three shafts, disposing veins of good widths throughout. No. 1 shaft shows the vein varying from 50 ins, with vaines from 49 dwts to 2 dwts, very constant, and having good indications of permanency. This shaft is already down to 150 ft. The No. 3 shaft, situated 1,200 ft from No. 1, is sunk to a relative depth of 110 ft, and on a level driven for 108 ft along the vein, it proved to be 30 ins wide, with an average vaine of 6 dwts. Our engineer, judging from the results so far obtained, only a small portion of this large property being so far explored, defines this as a ' valuable asset." The whole group of veins known as "B group" has yet to be exposed and the vaines established before the true worth of this roperly can be appreciated. Very briefly I have drawn yonr attention to some of thn points regarding these fine mining properties, but it is far more important to study the assay tables appended to car report. These show foot by foot the proved gold valons in the mires. demonstrating that these properties are slowly hot surely advancing from the exploring stage to that of valuable proved mines. I think yon will agree with me that although we are living through very bad times, as far as market are concerned, the resalts of our developments leave little to be desired, and am sure if times were normal there is no donbt we conld dispose of these properties on terms which would show a very handsome profit to the handsome profit to the shareholders of this company.
The Question of Equipment.

In accordance with the advice given by Mr. Alford in the concluding paragraphs of his report, we have given much careful attention to a scheme for the building of a railway, the erection of a battery at Keneh, and the equipment of our three mines with the necessary machinery for rapod development. The larger a buisness is and the more profitable it is, the more capital is required in its development and I have no hesitation whatever in recommending you all to take shares in the company which I hope will shortly be offered to you. Even if no more mines are discovered than the three for which we propose to take out mining leases, your shares should return you a handsome profit, and, in addition to these you must not forget that the building of the proposed railway will be of enormous advantage to us in the prospecting of the balance of our area, and probably result in the establishent of further gold mines. We know that there are many other mining centres in our concession, and we have only recently been approched by a group with a view to the working of some of these areas. We are not particualarly anxious to part with any of our ancient mines, because our experience has proved most conclusively that most of them are very valuable. We have, you may complain, moved slowly, but Ithink you must admit that we have also been extremely economical and careful, and that we have made very small sum which was avaliable to us last at a very long time. There is still enough money to keep us going. We have also unissued shares and other means of raising money such purposed as the compnay is likely to want capital, outside the heavy expenditure on three mines which must, I think you will agree, be undertaken by a seperate company. In conclusion, permit me to congratulate you on the success our efforts have so far accomplished. It is not possible to say what may be the value of the other yet unproved portions of our concession; that we shall taje in hand as soon as the present problem has been solved; but there is no reason for supposing that they will be less valuable than the properties to which has existed so long in mining securities generally may have passed away and that the investing public will see that gold mining in Egypt is no empty shadow and with as good a probability of paying handsome returns as gold minig in any other part of the world. Before formally moving the resolution, I should like to say that the directors, in view of cutting down expenses in all possible ways, have passed a resolution agreeing to take only half their fees during the current year. (Applause) I now beg to move "That the reports and accounts for the year ending 31st December, 1905 as presented to the meeting, be and they are hierahy recived and adopted.
The Outlook for further Mines

Mr. C. Weeding Skinners I have very much pleasure in aecquding the resolution, and I may say that I agree with all the conclusions the Chairman has pnt before you in his speech. As somé of you are aware, though perhaps not all, I am in a better position than most of you I to judge about these mines, simply fur the reason thit I have been all over the ground myself. When I came home from Egypt I told all my collegues on the Board and my friends who are shareholders in the company—and there are a great many of them—wbat I had been there, and the impression that the conntry had made on me. I am perfectly sure that between the particular properties which we have more or less developed there are scores more that we do not even know of—although we do know of many more (applause)—and, in my opinion, as I said when I came heme from Egypt, it is merely a matter of capital and time to make a very great deaTfif money for the shareholders in this company. (Applause.)

The Chairman : Before putting the resolution I shall be glad to answer any questions' which shareholders may ask. I have to add to what I told you about the reduction of the fees of the directors, that we have come to the conclusion that it will be well to husband our resources as much as ever we can, and, therefore, there being five gentlemen on the Board at present, one of onr number—thongh neither of those seeking re-election to day—will retire from the Board. We feel we can do the business of the company with four, and we desire in every way to meet the wishes of the shareholders in reducing expenses.
A Shareholder's Questions.

Mr. Vernon Roberts said there were two or three questions he desired to ask in regard to the accounts, which in their present form appeared to him to ba rather bald. He wished to know when the calls amounting to £1,666 entered on the liabilities side of the balance-sheet as being not yet payable would be payable, and on what terms these shares were issued. He believed that some public philanthropists took those shares up at par when they were standing at a heavy discount. He supposed the holders were waiting until a dividend was declared before they paid up their calls. On the assets side there was an item "less – by sale of shares and options." It would be interesting to know whether some of the company's Um Rus shares – or what shares – had been sold. On the last occasion the Chairman told them that the company had had such a prosperus yar that the directors decided to draw the whole of their fees. He desired to know whether, as they had done the same in the past year, they considered they had again had a very prospurous year, because it was certainly appeared to be a loss on paper of 4,999 on 6,666 shares in the Um Rus Compnay. The fact that the director proposed to taje half fees only in the current year did not make it appear as though they were looking forward to this year being prosperous. The speaker also asked for an explination of the item on the assets side of the balance sheet of "Sudan Mines – 200 shares surrendered for providing further working capital". It would also be interesting to know what were the holdings of the directors, and more particularly the two gentleman who were coming up for re-election on the present occasion. It seemed to him that if their holding was small it was to their benefit to keep the company going for the sake of their fees (Laughter).
The Chairman's Reply.

The Chairman said the item of calls not yet payable represented the balance due on 5,000 shares subscribed for at par at the end of 1903. They were applied for and allotted on condition that the paymenrs were spread over a period of about eighteen months. The 6,666 shares in the Um Rus Company represented this company's proportion of the new issue made by the Um Rus Company last spring. The company sold its rights at a profit of one sixteenth per share, but the purchase stipulated that they should only take delivery at certain periods. They had taken delivery at certain portion; the time had not yet arrived for the delivery of the balance. When the transfer had been completed, the company's holding in the Um Rus Company should be about 33,000 shares.Then a question had been asked as to why certain shares in the Sudan Mines were surrendered. That company had an offer from financiers to put some 5,000 or 7,000 upon terms, and approached the Board of this company as to whether they would render assistance. The Board considered it was very much to the interest of the company to help the Sudan Mines to improve their financial position. He was afraid he could not gratify the anxiety of the shareholders who had asked for details as ro the holdings of his collegues, but that could be ascertained from the register.

Mr. F. A. White said that in view of the sourness of the remarks made by the shareholder who had put several questions to the holder who had put several questions to the Chairman he would like to say that he thought the directors, who were doing their best for the good of the company, had given a very fair earnest of their intention to make some allowance for the bad times the company was going through by what they proposed to do— (hear, hear)—and it came with an exceedingly bad grace from the body of the meeting for one of their number to want to know whether the directes would give back some of the fees they had had. He objected very much to the tone of the remarks made. Everything he had heard reguarding the company gave him confidence in the directors and their management. (Hear, hear.)

The Chairnnn said he was very much obliged to the last speaker if that expression of opinion. The Board certainly thought that, in view of the times they had gone through, they had done extremely well fur this company.
A Shareholder : I should think so, too.

The Chairman added that his colleagues and himself did not wish to take themselves credit that they did not deserve, but he could say that they had worked in the best interests of the oompany and that they were determined to bring it to a snooessful issue. (Applause.)
Tho motion was then put and carried.

The Chairman proposed the re-election of Mr. C. Weeding Skinner as a direotor of the company, remarking that he was a most valuable member of the Board, seeing that he had bean all over the propeities and took a daily interest in the affairs of the company.
Sir Henry Banbury, Bart., seconded the motion, and it was carried unanimously.
On the motion of the Chairman, seconded by Mr. Skinner, Sir Henry Bunbnry was also re-elected a direotor.
Messrs. Pannell and Co. were reappointed and editors, and a vote of thanks to the Chairman and directors, on the motion of Sir Amemley C. Da Renzy, dosed the proceedings.

Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
